moves.1. c4 d5: My least favorite English response except it is weak here because it is played without preparation which guarantees that white gets a stronghold on d5.
moves.2. cxd5 Qxd5 3. Nc3 Qd8 4. e4 e5 5. Nf3: I would rather play white here than black.
moves.7. dxe5: Originally in the game I would have scored this move highly, now I notice that the recapture hangs the bishop and that either alternative bishop move protects the queen.  It's still a good move, but I think most players would come to the same decision.
moves.7... Bc7 8. Qxd8+: Spares me the trouble of immediately protecting the e5 pawn.
moves.8... Bxd8 9. Bc4 Ba5 10. O-O Nh6: 10...Bxc3.  I personally would rather have the bisop pair most of the time, but the teeth of his threat was removed when I castled away.  Later the knights prove pivotal.
moves.12. Nd5 Be6 13. Nf6+: This whole game, I just keep him from making the moves he would prefer to make.
moves.13... Ke7 14. Bxe6 Kxe6: The pawn capture is probably safer.
moves.15. Rfd1 Nc6 16. Rd6+ Ke7 17. Nh4 Nxe5: I neglected this when playing, but it turns out to be one of those situations where less is more.
22...Bb6 23.Nd7+  Yoshark adds the better move Re5 which creates a forced mate.  You can try your hand at finding it here: http://gameknot.com/chess-puzzle.pl?pz=25450

In the heat of battle we often find a powerful line and push it when a better solution exists even if our solution is winning!
moves.24... Rg8 25. Rxa8: And black cannot prevent mate.  Here black sent a request to abort the game.  When denied he played Rxg2+ which simply loses a rook.  After the rook loss he requested the move taken back.  Sure.  The rook is immaterial.  Then he resigned.
